text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Clinical
Trials Daily \-- Staff editors report on the newly launched clinical trial,
NCT04403360, which has the following summary description: "Lumbar spinae
stenosis surgery is a frequent intervention resulting in important
postoperative pain. Management of this postoperative pain is thus important.
Different pain management therapies exist. The erector spinae plane (ESP)
block was described in 2016. It involves the injection of local anesthetics
into the interfascial plane, deep to erector spinae muscle, allowing the
blockade of the dorsal and ventral rami of the thoracic spinal nerves. It was
initially proposed for analgesia of costal fractures, pulmonary lobectomy and
thoracic vertebrae. The ESP block (ESPB) could probably be extended to a large
number of surgical procedures. ESPB has so far not been investigated in lumbar
spinae stenosis surgery."

As a matter of record, on May 28, 2020, NewsRx staff editors report that the
available information provided by Clinique Saint Pierre Ottignies on this
trial include:

### Tracking Information

Trial Identifier| NCT04403360  
---|---  
**First Submitted Date**|  **May 21, 2020**  
First Posted Date| May 27, 2020  
Results First Submitted Date| Not Provided  
Results First Posted Date| Not Provided  
**Last Update Submitted Date**|  **May 21, 2020**  
Last Update Posted Date| May 27, 2020  
Primary Completion Date| December 31, 2020  
Actual Start Date| October 1, 2018  
Current Primary Outcome Measures| •Total 24 h Piritramide consumption [ Time
Frame: 24 hours ] -- Total consumption of Piritramide consumption after
surgery  
Current Secondary Outcome Measures| •Quebec back pain disability scale (QBPDS)
[ Time Frame: At 2 months] ] -- A questionnaire developed to measure the level
of functional disability for patients with low back pain  
Other Outcome Measures| Not Provided  
Change History| [Complete list of historical revisions of study
NCT04403360](https://clinicaltrials.gov/archive/NCT04403360)  
  
### Descriptive Information

Brief Title| Erector Spinae Plane Block After Lumbar Spinal Stenosis Surgery  
---|---  
Official Title| Impact of the Erector Spinae Plane Block on the Postoperative
Pain After Lumbar Spinal Stenosis Surgery: Single Blind Randomized Controlled
Trial  
Brief Summary| Lumbar spinae stenosis surgery is a frequent intervention
resulting in important postoperative pain. Management of this postoperative
pain is thus important. Different pain management therapies exist. The erector
spinae plane (ESP) block was described in 2016. It involves the injection of
local anesthetics into the interfascial plane, deep to erector spinae muscle,
allowing the blockade of the dorsal and ventral rami of the thoracic spinal
nerves. It was initially proposed for analgesia of costal fractures, pulmonary
lobectomy and thoracic vertebrae. The ESP block (ESPB) could probably be
extended to a large number of surgical procedures. ESPB has so far not been
investigated in lumbar spinae stenosis surgery.  
Detailed Description| Not Provided  
Study Type| Interventional  
Study Phase| N/A  
Study Design| Allocation: Randomized  
| Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment  
| Primary Purpose: Treatment  
| Masking: Single  
Condition| Lumbar Spinal Stenosis  
| Erector Spinae Plane Block  
Intervention| •Procedure: ESPB  
| Ultrasound guided performance of ESPB at T12 level after the induction of
anesthesia but before the start of the surgery  
| •Procedure: Local infiltration by the surgeon  
| Local infiltration of anesthetics at surgical site after skin incision  
Study Arms| •Experimental: Erector Spinae plane Block (ESPB) group  
| The ultrasound-guided ESPB was realized at T12 level (levo bupivacaine 0.25%
+ epinephrine 1:200.000 4mg.kg-1 body weight)after the induction of anesthesia
but before the start of the surgery.  
| Interventions:  
| ⚬Procedure: ESPB  
| •Active Comparator: Local anesthesia infiltration by the surgeon  
| The surgeon infiltrates the surgical site after skin incision with local
anesthetics (Levo Bupivacaine 0.25% + epinephrine 1:200.000 4mg.kg-1 body
weight)  
| Interventions:  
| ⚬Procedure: Local infiltration by the surgeon  
Publications*| *Includes publications given by the data provider as well as
publications identified by [ClinicalTrials.gov](http://ClinicalTrials.gov)
Identifier (NCT Number) in Medline  
| [PubMed Link](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed?term=27501016) \- Forero
M, Adhikary SD, Lopez H, Tsui C, Chin KJ. The Erector Spinae Plane Block: A
Novel Analgesic Technique in Thoracic Neuropathic Pain. Reg Anesth Pain Med.
2016 Sep-Oct;41(5):621-7. doi: 10.1097/AAP.0000000000000451.  
  
### Recruitment Information

Recruitment Status| Recruiting  
---|---  
Estimated Enrollment| 80  
Estimated Completion Date| April 1, 2021  
Primary Completion Date| December 31, 2020 (Final data collection date for
primary outcome measure)  
Eligibility| Inclusion Criteria:  
| •Any lumbar spinae surgery on 2 or more lumbar levels Exclusion Criteria:  
| •Contraindication to NSAID  
| •Allergy to any local anesthetics  
Sex/Gender| Sexes Eligible for Study: All  
Ages| 18 years to 99 years  
Accepts Healthy Volunteers| No  
Contacts| Primary contact: Georges SAMOURI, MD, 003210437260,
[georges.samouri@cspo.be](mailto:georges.samouri@cspo.be)  
| Backup contact: Nicolas PARISI, MD, 003210437608,
[nicolas.parisi@cspo.be](mailto:nicolas.parisi@cspo.be)  
Listed Location Countries| Belgium  
Removed Location Countries|  
  
### Administrative Information

NCT Number| NCT04403360  
---|---  
Other Study ID Numbers| B707201837276  
Has Data Monitoring Committee| Yes  
U.S. FDA-regulated Product| Not Provided  
Plan to Share Data| No  
Plan to Share Data (IPD) Description| All data will be presented in future
manuscripts.  
Responsible Party| Georges Samouri, Clinique Saint Pierre Ottignies  
Collaborators| Not Provided  
Investigators| Principal Investigator: Georges SAMOURI, MD, Clinique Saint
Pierre Ottignies  
Information Provided By| Clinique Saint Pierre Ottignies  
Verification Date| May 2020  
  
(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Impact of the Erector Spinae Plane Block on the Postoperative Pain After Lumbar Spinal Stenosis Surgery: Single Blind Randomized Controlled Trial: Musculoskeletal Diseases and Conditions - Spinal Stenosis
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Clinical Trials Daily -- Staff editors report on the newly launched clinical trial, NCT04403360, which has the following summary description: “Lumbar spinae stenosis surgery is a frequent intervention resulting in important postoperative pain. Management of this postoperative pain is thus important. Different pain management therapies exist. The erector spinae plane (ESP) block was described in 2016. It involves the injection of local anesthetics into the interfascial plane, deep to erector spinae muscle, allowing the blockade of the dorsal and ventral rami of the thoracic spinal nerves. It was initially proposed for analgesia of costal fractures, pulmonary lobectomy and thoracic vertebrae. The ESP block (ESPB) could probably be extended to a large number of surgical procedures. ESPB has so far not been investigated in lumbar spinae stenosis surgery.”

As a matter of record, on May 28, 2020, NewsRx staff editors report that the available information provided by Clinique Saint Pierre Ottignies on this trial include:

Tracking Information

Trial IdentifierNCT04403360
First Submitted DateMay 21, 2020
First Posted DateMay 27, 2020
Results First Submitted DateNot Provided
Results First Posted DateNot Provided
Last Update Submitted DateMay 21, 2020
Last Update Posted DateMay 27, 2020
Primary Completion DateDecember 31, 2020
Actual Start DateOctober 1, 2018
Current Primary Outcome Measures•Total 24 h Piritramide consumption [ Time Frame: 24 hours ] -- Total consumption of Piritramide consumption after surgery
Current Secondary Outcome Measures•Quebec back pain disability scale (QBPDS) [ Time Frame: At 2 months] ] -- A questionnaire developed to measure the level of functional disability for patients with low back pain
Other Outcome MeasuresNot Provided
Change HistoryComplete list of historical revisions of study NCT04403360

Descriptive Information

Brief TitleErector Spinae Plane Block After Lumbar Spinal Stenosis Surgery
Official TitleImpact of the Erector Spinae Plane Block on the Postoperative Pain After Lumbar Spinal Stenosis Surgery: Single Blind Randomized Controlled Trial
Brief SummaryLumbar spinae stenosis surgery is a frequent intervention resulting in important postoperative pain. Management of this postoperative pain is thus important. Different pain management therapies exist. The erector spinae plane (ESP) block was described in 2016. It involves the injection of local anesthetics into the interfascial plane, deep to erector spinae muscle, allowing the blockade of the dorsal and ventral rami of the thoracic spinal nerves. It was initially proposed for analgesia of costal fractures, pulmonary lobectomy and thoracic vertebrae. The ESP block (ESPB) could probably be extended to a large number of surgical procedures. ESPB has so far not been investigated in lumbar spinae stenosis surgery.
Detailed DescriptionNot Provided
Study TypeInterventional
Study PhaseN/A
Study DesignAllocation: Randomized
Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment
Primary Purpose: Treatment
Masking: Single
ConditionLumbar Spinal Stenosis
Erector Spinae Plane Block
Intervention•Procedure: ESPB
Ultrasound guided performance of ESPB at T12 level after the induction of anesthesia but before the start of the surgery
•Procedure: Local infiltration by the surgeon
Local infiltration of anesthetics at surgical site after skin incision
Study Arms•Experimental: Erector Spinae plane Block (ESPB) group
The ultrasound-guided ESPB was realized at T12 level (levo bupivacaine 0.25% + epinephrine 1:200.000 4mg.kg-1 body weight)after the induction of anesthesia but before the start of the surgery.
Interventions:
⚬Procedure: ESPB
•Active Comparator: Local anesthesia infiltration by the surgeon
The surgeon infiltrates the surgical site after skin incision with local anesthetics (Levo Bupivacaine 0.25% + epinephrine 1:200.000 4mg.kg-1 body weight)
Interventions:
⚬Procedure: Local infiltration by the surgeon
Publications**Includes publications given by the data provider as well as publications identified by ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier (NCT Number) in Medline
PubMed Link - Forero M, Adhikary SD, Lopez H, Tsui C, Chin KJ. The Erector Spinae Plane Block: A Novel Analgesic Technique in Thoracic Neuropathic Pain. Reg Anesth Pain Med. 2016 Sep-Oct;41(5):621-7. doi: 10.1097/AAP.0000000000000451.

Estimated Enrollment80

EligibilityInclusion Criteria:
•Any lumbar spinae surgery on 2 or more lumbar levels Exclusion Criteria:
•Contraindication to NSAID
•Allergy to any local anesthetics
Sex/GenderSexes Eligible for Study: All
